The graph below shows what happens to point $L$ when you rotate the figure $-90^\circ$ about the point $(-4,2)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b11080f4ad3658739097c95b5cd0fafacfb51081.png)

The path from the rotation point $(-4,2)$ to point $L(7,-3)$ is:  
$\begin{align}
\purple{11} \text{ in the} &x \text{ direction}  \\
\red{-5} \text{ in the} &y\text{ direction}  \\
\end{align}$

The path from the rotation point $(-4,2)$ to the new point $L'$, will be rotated $90^\circ$ clockwise, as shown.  
$\begin{align}
\red{-5} \text{ in the} &x\text{ direction}  \\
\purple{-11} \text{ in the} &y\text{ direction}  \\
\end{align}$

We can use these values to calculate the coordinates of the new point.  
$L'$ has the coordinates $(-4+\red{-5},2+\purple{-11})$ = $(-9,-9)$

Note: For a rotation of $-90^\circ$, the path will always change from:  
$\begin{align}
\purple{a} \text{ in the} &x \text{ direction}  \\
\red{b} \text{ in the} &y\text{ direction}  \\
\end{align}$  
to:  
$\begin{align}
\red{b} \text{ in the} &x\text{ direction}  \\
\purple{-a} \text{ in the} &y\text{ direction}  \\
\end{align}$

It may be helpful to think of it like the radial symmetry we see on a pinwheel or the blades of a windmill or a fan.

Using the same pattern, we can transform the other vertices.

The path from the rotation point $(-4,2)$ to point $P(4,5)$ is:

$\begin{align}
\purple{11} \text{ in the} &x \text{ direction}  \\
\red{4} \text{ in the} &y\text{ direction}  \\
\end{align}$

The path from the rotation point $(-4,2)$ to the new point $A'$, will be:  
$\begin{align}
